awd_titl_txt: CPS: Medium: Quantitative Contract-Based Synthesis and Verification for CPS Security
awd_abstract_narration:
Cyber-physical systems (CPS) are deployed in safety-critical and mission-critical applications for which security is a primary design concern. At the same time, these systems must be designed to be more flexible to changing requirements and environment conditions. This project pursues foundational work on a new methodology for CPS design to enable a "plug-and-play" approach that also ensures the security and safety of the system from the design phase. Such a principled design approach can have an enormous positive impact on the emerging national "smart" infrastructure. Through collaborations with industry partners, the project aims to improve the design process in the CPS industry with a particular focus on automotive systems. Additionally, this project plans to integrate research into undergraduate and graduate coursework, especially capstone projects, and will have an impact on the textbooks and online course content developed by the researchers.

This project develops a fundamentally new theory for quantitative contract-based design of CPS that balances security requirements with critical safety and performance concerns. This theory meets a pressing need faced by industrial cyber-physical systems, which are being transformed by a push towards "plug-and-play" design architectures. This push tends to upend the design process for CPS, bringing with it renewed concerns about security and privacy.  The proposed approach has the following key components: (i) a precise interface specification for each "plug-in" component in a novel quantitative temporal logic; (ii) rapid, run-time verification methods for checking component conformance to specifications, and (iii) A new approach for mapping components onto existing architectures while satisfying performance and security specifications, and minimizing costs. The approach will be developed and evaluated in an industrial automotive context. The proposed rigorous logic-based formalism, backed by algorithmic advances in verification and synthesis, has the potential to create new fundamental science and help put the industrial trend towards plug-and-play architectures on a firm footing.

por.por_cntn:
Contract-based design was introduced to enable a formal component-based approach for CPSs. This NSF project significantly extended the capabilities of this theory and methodology by allowing it to be applied to any design attribute of interest to a designer, including security that has come to the attention of governments, industry and academia as a foremost concern. The project resulted in the following major accomplishments:


(i) Intellectual merit:

 
We began by identifying and defining several key operations in the theory of assume-guarantee contracts that were missing or unknown. We were able to derive a closed-form for the quotient, separation, and merging operations, all of them of relevance to enabling a formal compositional methodology. Our work on these algebraic aspects led to the realization that contracts share structure with other compositional theories that been proposed for a rigorous approach to system design; this led to the identification of an underlying algebraic definition, called preordered heaps, of which several existing theories are instances.

Motivated by the consideration that there are  important system attributes that traditional assume-guarantee contracts cannot express, and in particullar,  important security properties (such as secure information-flow and non-interference), we introduced the theory of hypercontracts, which supports compositional reasoning of all known formal properties that can be assigned to a system and that can be used to assess security properties.

This project has also contributed towards UCLID5, a novel open-source toolkit for the formal modeling, verification, and synthesis of computational systems, which has been effectively applied to reasoning about system security.

Finally, we developen a novel approach to CPS security based on an architecture,called the cyber-physical immune system, inspired by the immune system of mammals. 


(ii) Broader impacts: 

Results from the proposed work have had impacts on teaching, on industrial practice, and on the mentoring of graduate  (PhD and Master of Engineering) and undergraduate students and postdoctoral researchers. The contract-based design approach has been successfully applied to a safe drone design including the use of hypercontracts to encode and enforce security properties.  Technology developed in the project has been taught in graduate classes on system design and formal methods, in an undergraduate class on Embedded/Cyber-Physical Systems, and in class projects, incorporated work by Master of Engineering researchers,and has contributed to the development of material to teach CPS in a remote setting.
